alert.note: Alert for Wahkiakum (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Portland (Northwest Oregon and Southwest Washington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 28 at 3:26AM PST until March 01 at 4:16PM PST by NWS Portland
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Portland OR has issued a Flood Warning for the following river in Washington... Grays River near Rosburg affecting Wahkiakum County. .Occasionally heavy rainfall has caused the Grays River to rise sharply overnight and early this morning. Up to 2 inches of rain had already fallen in the Willapa Hills as of 3 AM Monday. Another 2 to 3 inches of rain are expected by the time rain diminishes late Monday night or early Tuesday morning. Snowmelt from higher elevations of the Willapa Hills will contribute to runoff as well. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS MORNING TO TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Grays River near Rosburg. * WHEN...From this morning to tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...Above 12.0 feet, expect some flooding of roads along and near the Grays River, including roadway approaches to the Altoona Bridge over the Grays, and portions of Covered Bridge Road, Barr-Durrah Road, and Loop Road near Rosburg and Hwy 4. Above 14.0 feet, expect widespread lowland flooding and numerous flooded roads near Rosburg and Hwy 4. This includes the roadway approaches to the Altoona Bridge over the Grays River. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:15 AM PST Monday the stage was 9.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this morning to a crest of 13.6 feet late this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage late tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued this afternoon at 400 PM PST.
